div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,573] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINE, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m., a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1906.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive is expected to arrive to-day at Alexandria from Europe, and with his Highness's return Egypt may be said to have ended its summer exodus. His Highness has had an interesting and, we trust, an invigorating holiday, having, we hope, much benefitted by his cure at Kissingen. His sojourn in Europe has not been one of pleasure only, having regard to his interview's with the most august sovereigns of Europe, including the Sultan of Turkey with whom we have reason to believe he is on the best of terms, notwithstanding occasional rumours to the contrary. His visits to France Belgium, Germany, and Austria, where at Vienna his Highness had an audience of the doyen of Western potentates, have no doubt kept him abreast of "Weltpolitik" and diplomacy, and in each country he has been received with all the honour and consideration due to his high position and personal charm. In this connection it is perhaps fitting to recall to the minds of Englishmen the important part played by the Khedive in the earlier stages of the negotiations' relative to the Tabah incident and the firmness and tact he displayed in asserting the rights of Egypt and there-by strengthening the attitude assumed by the British Government. The delicate position in which he was placed during that crisis was, however, probably insignificant compared with the complexity of the situation which has so unfortunately arisen since his departure. To, act loyally towards the occupying Power without ever giving umbrage to other States, whilst at the same time retaining among his own subjects the prestige and popularity he has so justly earned can be by no means an easy matter for his Highness even under normal conditions, whereas at periods of stress and effervescence like the present, the difficulties of that task must be immeasurably increased. It will need all the skill and diplomacy at his Highness's command to cope with the conflicting streams of tendency recently observable and to reconcile the mutually hostile aims of those who are fomenting the prevailing unrest. We cannot but express a hope that in this endeavour he may be thoroughly successful and that through his influence the country may be quickly restored to its wonted calm.

div.head: TOLERATION IN MALTA.
div.p: In another column we publish an instructive communication from Lord Elgin on the question of maintaining religious toleration throughout the British Empire. Lord Elgin lays down an unimpeachable principle of British rule in informing the Governor of Malta that amended Royal Instructions will in future guarantee "full liberty of conscience and the free exercise of their respective modes of religious worship to all creeds without distinction in the island. The instruction is the result of the discovery made last May, in consequence of the Roman Catholic Archbishop's protest against a militant Protestant mission, that the Roman Catholic Church stood in a privileged position in Malta as regards public religious ceremonies. However, even now the condition is appended that the exercise of equal rights must be "quiet and peaceable and not "give offence or scandal to the Government." A religious procession that would suit Madrid might make trouble in Liverpool, and a Salvation Army open-air service that would cause no particular scandal in Camberwell would excite a grave one in Mecca. Malta is Malta, and the Governor may find it rather delicate work to decide how far polemical propaganda can be tolerated.

div.p: Yesterday an Austrian workman was shot at Kom-Ombo.

div.p: A large new shelter house for pilgrims will
be built shortly at Port Tewfik.

div.head: Chilian Training Ship
div.p: The Chilian training-ship Generale Baquedano left Alexandria at half-past ten this morning.

div.head: Alexandria Native Court.
div.p: There are 28 criminal cases to be disposed of at the Alexandria Criminal Court on Saturday next.

div.head: Cattle Plague.
div.p: It has been decided to include the Bibeh district among those parts of the country held to be infected with cattle plague.

div.head: Robbery at a Prince's Palace.
div.p: Prince Haidar Pasha Fazel has informed the police that a robbery has been committed in his residence at Sharia Fehmi, and that valuables worth £150 have been removed.

div.head: Contracts.
div.p: The contract for the prolongation of the Mit el Aml drain, Zifta circle, has been given to M. Patrachini. The contract for the construction of a new storey of the Irrigation rest- house, Zifta circle, has been given to M. Matta Khalil.

div.head: "Al Moayad."
div.p: To-day "Al Moayad" will appear in an increased size. Instead of eight pages of five columns, it will contain eight pages of six columns, the pages being of a much large size. A new electric rotary machine, turning out 12,000 copies per hour, is to be used for publishing our contemporary.

div.head: The Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: To night the Turkish troupe conclude their short visit to the Alhambra Theatre with Les Trois Locataires and the Oriental operetta Leblebidji Hor-Hor-Agha. To-morrow Mlle Mary Fleur, the well-known Italian artiste, and La Belle Liliane, fresh from her triumphs at Cairo, will make their debut. On Thursday Zane's marrionette company will commence their series of four representations.

div.head: Cairo Fire Station.
div.p: According to the "Bosphore," the clock tower of the Cairo fire station is dangerously cracked, so much so that the Commandant of Police urges the Ministry of the Interior to have it demolished and rebuilt. Mansfield Pasha has at the same time observed, says our contemporary, that the L.E. 28.000 spent on the station were thrown away, as the whole building leaves much to be desired.

div.head: The Labbane Affair.
div.p: Onbashi Mohamed Taha and Shawish Abdel- Aal, to whom the recent sensational death of a witness at the Labban Caracol was wrongly ascribed, were brought this morning before a Council of Discipline, held at the Alexandria Gouvernorat under the presidency of Yousbashi Bishara Effendi Nushi. The sentence will not be made public until it has been confirmed by the Ministry of the Interior.

div.head: Khedivial School of Law.
div.p: Sir Malcolm McIlwraith, Judicial Adviser, and Monsieur Bernard Bey, senior French Inspector of the Ministry of Public Instruction, have been interviewing in Paris during the past week candidates for the headmastership of the Khedivial School of Law, Cairo, and have selected Monsieur Lambert, Professor of Civil Law in the University of Lyons. The new Principal is expected to enter upon his duties in Cairo on the 22nd inst.

div.head: A Novel on Egypt.
div.p: Sir Gilbert Parker has spent five years of spare time upon a new novel which will begin publication in the October number of "Harper's Magazine." It is a story of England and Egypt, and tendencies in both countries, and with the effect of Egyptian atmosphere and tradition upon Western temperament. The novel is called "The Weavers," and will be illustrated by M. André Castaigne, who has recently made many studies in the East for the purpose of doing justice to his story.

div.head: Charity Fete.
div.p: A society of charitable ladies have taken the initiative to organize a fête at San Stefano Casino in support of the asylum for aged seamen, kept by the "Little Sisters of the Poor." This admirable institution, which receives freely the aged and infirm of all nationalities and religions, is well known to every one. The fête will take place on Sunday, October 7, and has special attractions for children. At a meeting at the French Consulate, yesterday, under the presidency of Mme. Pierre Girard, the following gifts towards the lottery were acknowledged: M. Charles Bacos, 2 Crédit Foncier Egyptien Bonds ; M. Alfred Campos, 1 ; M. John Sinadino, 1 ; and M. George Zervudachi, 2. M. Emin Caram, on behalf of Mme Emin Caram, 1.000 francs ; Mme. Michel Reizian Bey, and Mme. Alexakis 300 P T.

div.head: New Employment Registry.
div.p: The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head:
THE CUBAN CRISIS.
DISARMAMENT COMMENCED.
OCCUPATION REGARDED PERMANENT.

div.p: 450 American marines landed here and have gone to Cienfuegos and other places in order to tranquillize the native mind. 6,000 troops will be landed within 10 days. The disarmament of the Government forces has begun. Commissions will be sent to disarm the revolutionaries.( Reuter)
The glowing disposition in the United States is to regard the occupation of Cuba as permanent. (Reuter)

div.head: INTERNATIONAL BALLOON RACE WON BY AMERICA.

div.p: Sixteen balloons, of which three were British, have started on the race for the International Gordon Bennett Cup. The winner must remain forty-eight hours in the air. (Reuter)

The competitors in the balloon race are scattered far and wide. Several came down in France near the Channel. M. Santos Dumont was injured in the arm and gave up. The others are traversing England in a northerly direction. There is no news of several of the competitors.
(Later). Seven balloonists, two of whom were English, have crossed the Channel. Nine landed in France. The American Fahm won the Cup. The balloon landed near Whitby. The time was 23 hours.(Reuter)

The correspondent of the "Daily Mail" at Hong Kong reports that another typhoon occurred on Saturday. The repair works on the wharves were destroyed. The whole sea front is a stream of wreckage. ( Reuter)

The Scotch Express from King's Cross had a narrow escape from destruction. After passing over the high level bridge over the Tyne it collided with a light engine before reaching Newcastle station. The engine was derailed and the track torn up. The passengers suffered no injuries. They had to walk into Newcastle.
( Reuter)
The Sikh police have reluctantly returned to duty. (Reuter)
The Dreadnought has left Portsmouth for 10 days trials, first of turbines then of guns. The Admiralty regard the trials as most important, consequently the results will be kept secret. (Reuter)

The Premier, M. Sarrien, speaking at an agricultural banquet, said that the Government did not desire religious persecutions, but that it would in no way agree to see the State submissive to the imperious demands of the Church. (Reuter)
Mr. Spring Rice has arrived. (Reuter)
The court-martial has condemned 19 naval mutineers to death and 112 to hard labour.
( (Havas)
H.H. the Khedive has left for Egypt, after being received in farewell audience by the Sultan. (Havas)
It is believed that the success of the South African footballers will be equal to that of the New Zealanders. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE SINAITIC BOUNDARY.
SATISFACTORY SETTLEMENT CONFIRMED.
AGREEMENT SIGNED YESTERDAY.
div.p: The maps which were prepared three months ago by the Anglo-Egyptian Commissioners, who have been engaged in common with the Turkish Commissioners in surveying the Sinaitic eastern boundary, have been approved and signed by the latter. The Turkish force which was occupying Kuseimeh has been withdrawn, and it is confidently expected that the final stage in the settlement of the delimitation dispute has been reached. The demands of the Egyptian Government have been fully satisfied.
(By Telephone)
Caire, 1 p.m.

The Turco-Egyptian Boundary agreement was signed yesterday, and weare glad to state that the settlement is from every point of view most satisfactory. The frontier as now delimitated follows approximately a straight line from Rafah to a point on the coast three miles west of Akaba. Only one deviation has been admitted, a small concession having been made to Turkey in the immediate neighbourhood of Akaba itself. From Rafah the line follows the watershed leaving the important point of Gufaima Ain Ragbdeif, the ancient Kadesh of the Exodus, on the Egyptian side of the line and Raf Rabadi to Raf Tabah, a cape at the head of the Gulf of Akaba. Tabah post on the upper portion of the pass between Akaba and Port Nakhl are retained by Egypt. The rights of the Bedouins to water and other properties on either side of the line are guaranteed by the parties to the agreement. Turkish troops and Zaptiehs are allowed to make use of the wells on the Egyptian side of the frontier but a special clause expressly prohibits them from crossing the frontier while carrying arms.
Now that all causes of friction are removed we trust that the good relations between Egypt and the Ottoman Empire will hence forth be maintained.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL RECEPTION.
div.p: On the occasion of his return to Egypt, H.H. the Khedive will hold on Saturday a reception at Ras el-Tin, to take place in the following order :—
9 a.m. The Princes of the Khedivial Family; the Ulema ; the President and members of the Cabinet.
9.30 a.m. The Councillors; the Under-Secretaries of State ; the Heads of the State Administrations.
10 a.m. The magistrates of the Mixed Tribunals ; the magistrates of the Native Courts ; the officers of the Army and Navy of the rank of Bimbasbi and upwards ; the civil officials.

10.30 a.m. Civil and military non officials, with the ranks of Lewa or Oulas Sinf Sani, and upwards ; officers of the Army ard Navy on leave or retiring, with the rank of Miralai or Kaimakam ; non-official Beys with the rank of Moutamaiz or Sanieh ; the members of Municipal Commission.
11. a.m. The Diplomatic and Consular Bodies. '
11.15 a.m. The superior officers of the Army of Occupation; the Clergy.
11.30 a.m. The native notables and merchants ; the European notables and merchants.
Her Highness the Khedivah will receive the same day between 10 and 11.30 a.m., the Princesses of the Khedivial Family and the native ladies.

On the 26th ult. the Khedive honoured the Persian Ambassador to the Sublime Porte Prince Arfa el-Dowlah, Mirza Rizah Khan, with his presence at a lunch at the Embassy. Among those who were also present were El Mirmindar Husny Pasha, Colonel Hassan Bey, Zeky Pasha, Izzet Bey, Mirza Mustapha Khan, the Persian Consular Staff, and Mirza Aly Akbar Khan, Persian Consul-General at Jeddah.

div.head: THE BUBONIC PLAGUE.
div.p: The weekly bulletin issued by the Department of Public Health reports that twelve cases occurred throughout Egypt during the week ended last Saturday, viz. 9 at Suez and 3 at Alexandria. Since January 1st the total number of cases recorded amounts to 475 as against 259 and 808 during the corresponding periods of 1905 and 1904, respectively. On Sunday a native of Moharrem Bey was found dead and bubonic plague was diagnosed, and on the same day one pneumonic case was admitted to hospital at Suez, where three deaths from plague also occurred. The four cases admitted to hospital at Suez on Saturday were all Maltese living in the same house.
Another death occurred yesterday in Suez hospital.
A porter, without any fixed abode, was admitted yesterday into the Government hospital at Alexandria suffering from plague.

div.head: CAIRO ZOOLOGICAL GARDENS.
div.p: A bear, which has been presented to the Cairo Zoological Gardens by Dr. Cerard, was received at Ghizeh by Captain Stanley Flower yesterday morning.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.
div.p: The Casino will remain open until the 30th October.

div.head: EGYPTIAN STATE RAILWAYS. THE NEW GENERAL MANAGER.
div.p: The appointment of a successor to the late Major L'Estrange Johnstone as general manager of the Egyptian State Railways will not be announced immediately. The difficulty of appointing a capable and practical man from England is very greatas such positions are very highly paid, salaries of from £5,000 to £6,000 not being uncommon. It might of course be possible to find a good man, who would accept the post at a salary ot £3,000 a year, but it would be a difficult task, as such a selection requires as an essential preliminary condition that the Egyptian Government should be in touch with the home railways in order to pick out a good man. In all such appointments the amount of the salary is a guage of the portion— Sir George Gibb, we believe, draws £8.000 a —year and it is quite out of the question for the Government to pay a sufficient salary, which would ensure it obtaining the services of the very best candidate. Under such circumstances it is not improbable that the Government may confine itself to making the appointment from the existing staff of the railways and, if so, Captian Blakeney would be in the running for the post.

div.head: LAND BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: It will be remembered that at the extraordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the Land Bank of Egypt, which was held in Alexandria on September 8, the creation of a further £2,500,000 of debentures was authorised, making the total authorised £5 000,000. The amount at present issued is £1,000,000 in 50 000 three and-a-half per cent. bonds of 500f. (£20), and a further issue of 90,000 four per cent. bonds of 500f. each will shortly be made. The fall details of this issue will be found in the financial portion of to-day's issue.

div.head: MR. BLUNT'S ANTI-NATIONALISM.
div.p: "Al Mokattam" makes the following comments on Mr. Blunt's campaign against his mother country :—

The article of the "Times," which we reproduced the day before yesterday, indicates clearly that it was Mr. Blunt who kindled the fire of Arabi's insurrection. The reader may think that this charge has been a bit exaggerated, but Mr. Blunt himself admits it. In an article published in the "Nineteenth Century" of September 1892 be wrote as follows :—

"I have often asked myself in view of all that happened since (the coming of the English fleet to Alexandria, etc. ) whether I did rightly at that crisis in using what influence I had over Arabi and the fellah leaders in encouraging them to stand firm, and weighing all the chances I have satisfied myself that I was not wrong. What indeed would have happened if Arabi had been false to his principles, if he had accepted the bribe of £4,000 a year which was offered to him, if he had bowed to the threats of Sir Beauchamp Seymour and Derwish Pasha and Sir Edward Malet, if he had basely left the country after having handed over the War Ministry and the command of the troops to the Circassian Omar Lutfi... The Anglo French regime would have gained a new lease of life. It needed the object lesson of a war to convince Englishmen that the Egyptian fellah had wrongs at all ; it needed the bombardment of Alexandria, the despatch of 30.000 British troops, the expenditure of I know not how many millions sterling, the disaster of the Sudan and Gordon's death."

This is Mr. Blunt's statement ten years after the insurrection. We, and all sane people would say to him : Had Arabi accepted the English Admiral's offer and left Egypt he would have led a respectable life. Alexandria would not have been bombarded, the forts would have been spared, the treasury would not have had to pay £9,000,000 for indemnities. The lives of thousands of ex Egyptian soldiers would have been spared, both in Egypt and in the Sudan, the Sudan rebellion would not have taken place and the European interference in Egypt would have been limited to the Dual control. We do not say that things are not better now than they were before, but it is not so in the eyes of Mr. Blunt and his friends unless his object is to have Egypt annexed to England and the bondholders will then be secure.

Our readers can see plainly from the above that England and Turkey tried to crush the rebellionby peaceful means and promised Arabi £4,000 a year if he would leave the country, but Mr. Blunt insisted on his refusing the offer. Yes, he insisted on Arabi holding out, pretending that Gladstone was under his thumb (Blunt's) and that he would never allow Alexandria to be bombarded. Blunt's premises did not come true: Alexandria was bombarded, the English occupied Egypt, and Mr. Blunt still pretends that what he did was right.

div.head: THE HAVAS AGENCY.
div.p: Commenting upon the ' Havas" telegram of Sunday's date regarding Mustapha Pasha Kamel, the "Progès" remarks as follows:— Nous savons parfaitement que, moyennant un petit bakschiche à l'Agence Havas, chacun peut s'offrir le luxe de faire connaître ses faits et gestes au monde entier. Mais nous nous permettrons de remarquer qu'il ne sied pas à une Agence qui reçoit les communications officielles du gouvernement français de faire continuellement de la réclame pour un intrigant, dont les buts inavouables et les menées dangereuses ont été signalées, dans le "Temps," par le directeur général des services de l'Agence en Orient.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in the spirit of fair play to all, to permit--within certain necessary limits--free discussion.

div.head: THE CASE OF ALI BEY,
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir, - In "Ali Bey's Reply" as published in your issue of to-day, he remarks in the first part of his letter in referring to his trial before a General Court Martial on a charge of cowar- dice "where no one is allowed to be present besides the members of the court." Will you kindly allow me to remind Ali Bey that this statement, as well as the remainder of his letter is inexact, as every court martial held in the Egyptian army from February 1883 was held with open doors, and the public was always admitted and even encouraged to be present by every Sirdar from Wood to Wingate inclusive ?

The other part of his letter has been sufficiently contradicted by the General Court- Martial, which after "well and truly trying him" found him guilty of "Cowardice" and sentenced him accordingly, which finding and sentence were duly "confirmed" by his Highness the Khedive, and which, no matter how Ali Bey would like to explain it otherwise, constitute "the true circumstances of his case." He was charged and tried as "an officer of his Highness' Regular Forces."—Faithfully Yours.
One who was present, (Not a Syrian.)

div.head: OFFICIALS AND CIVILIANS.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,—It is difficult to understand how a "civilian official" up in the Fayoum, can take upon himself to assert that of which he has no means of knowing, viz : the vast entertainment afforded to officials and all the "common commercial herd." Sensible and educated unbiassed readers can only read English as it is written, and the attempt to separate the commercial class of Englishmen, leaving the other nationalities to form the "common herd," is certainly a sop to Cerberus, but only intensifies the gross insult, wantonly offered, to the whole cosmopolitan community of respectable commercial people. My opinion is that the civilian officials, far from being excessively amused over the letter in your issue of 26th inst., will be filled with chagrin and bitter vexation, that the remarks therein were ever invoked, and so they richly deserve to be. As regards the substance of "Vox Clamantis'" letter in your issue of the 23rd inst., I will relate what occurred, in a quiet and respectable quarter of Cairo, in the small hours of this morning :— Five or six of these "civilian officials," returning from a Bacchanalian orgie, and after hammering and making an outrageons noise to arouse the bowab, as well as the other inmates of the house, managed by great effort to leave one or two of their number, who were unable to look after themselves, and those who were left began to discuss in vile English the modus operandi of getting to their own lodgings. This sort of conduct, together with remarks far from refined (especially from one who seemed anxious to let the world know, if possible, that he had got outside of several glasses of champagne, four whiskeys and sodas, and several liquers, and proposed to go back to the Turf Club, etc) may be very edifying and instructive to these particular officials, but was only offensive and disgusting to the other occupants of the house, who without exception, according to the cognomen bestowed upon them in the letter of your issue 22nd September, belong to the "common herd" of commercial people, who at any rate, know how to behave themselves decently, and would never descend for the rowdyism etc. of civilian officials. I fully coincide with "Vox Clamantis," and consider that it is the imperative duty of the heads of ministries, departments etc. to interfere, in the interests of public comfort, to issue stringent orders to their employés (this term of course includes civilian officials though they may not wish it to be thought so) against this sort of behaviour, and make examples when necessary, if only to prove that the lustre of England's greatness must not be tarnished in a foreign land, by any whipper-snapper who chooses to try and do so. Apologising for taking up so much space,
I am, Yours faithfully, Ex Officio. Cairo, September 30.

[We must apologise to "Ex Officio" for not having published in extenso the text of his letter, but, so great is the demand upon the space which is required by our correspondents that we feel obliged to omit the less forcible arguments of both sides. Ed. E. G.]

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan has arrived at the Piræus from Corfu on his steam yacht. After a stay at Athens his Highness will proceed direct to Alexandria.
Mohamed Pasha Mohsen has postponed his departure from Alexandria as owing to the arrival of the Khedive his Excellency has to attend the reception at Ras el-Tin Palace on Saturday next
Sir Reginald Oakes, the manager of the Heliopolis Oasis Company, it staying at the Grand Hotel Mongolie, Brussels.
Mr. Cornish, C.M.G, Managing director of the Alexandria Water Company, has arrived at the Lake of Como from Samaken in the Engadine. He will return to Alexandria in the first week of next month.
M. Guermonprez, French Consular Attaché at Alexandria, has been appointed the French Consulate at Geneva.

Lady Cromer's brother, the Marquessof Bath, is having Lake Shearwater, on his estate at Longleaf, drained, in order to destroy thé growth of water-lilies. Large quantities of fish, including some immense trout, have been found, and numbers have been kept for the purpose of re-stocking the lake.

div.head: QUESTIONS MUNICIPALES
POIDS ET MESURES
div.p: Depuis que la Municipalité existe, elle n'a rien fait pour réglementer les poids et mesures. Les plaintes incessantes du public, les interpellations d'un conseiller municipal, les critiques de la presse, n'ont eu aucun écho, et le public, victime déjà de la hausse énorme des loyers et du renchérissement continu des denrées alimentaires, doit encore assister impuissant aux vols quotidiens pratiqués à son préjudice par ses fournisseurs au moyen des faux poids.

Nos confrères se sont plaints comme nous de cet état de choses, mais quelques-uns d'entre eux en rendent le gouvernement responsable. C'est une erreur. La question est assez importante pour que nous établissions clairement les responsabilités une fois pour toutes.

M. Zouro, appuyé par la presse et en particulier par "l'Egyptian Gazette," fit sa première interpellation sur les poids et mesures le 28 décembre 1904. Il signalait les abus commis par les débitants et réclamait une règlementation et un contrôle des halles et marchés.

Peu après, la Délégation présentait un projet simple et pratique de nature à mettre fin aux abus et qui consistait pour la Municipalité à tenir en dépôt une série complète de poids et mesures règlementaires, à remettre d autres séries analogues à des fonctionnaires établis sur divers points de la ville, à timbrer les poids et mesures des commerçants, à contrôler continuellement l'exactitude des poids et mesures sur les marchés.
Le 29 Mars 1905 la Commission adoptait cette manière de voir et décidait de communiquer le projet de la Délégation au ministère.

Après cela, nous constatons un silence d'une année. C'est, en effet, le 24 Mars 1906 que M. Zouro interpelle de nouveau l'administra-trion sur la suite qui a été donnée à la délité ration sur les poids et mesures. M. l'administrateur répond " que, l'affaire intéressant " le paya tout entier, la Municipalité a cru "devoir attendre l'élaboration du règlement "du gouvernement, qui sera appliqué à la "ville d'Alexandrie." M. Zouro réplique que la ville d'Alexandrie ne demande pas une règlementation pour toute l'Egypte, générale et définitive, mais provisoire sur les seules denrées alimentaires et uniquement pour la ville d'Alexandrie ; la population est trop intéressée pourqu'on la fasse attendre.

M. l'Administrateur insiste sur sa première déclaration : le ministère, dit-il, s'oppose à cette règlementation, et la Commission Municipale, ajoute-t-il, n'ayant pas mis d'objection à la suggestion du ministère, il s'ensuit que l'administration n'est nullement responsable du retard apporté à la règlementation des poids et mesures.
Malheureusement pour M. l'administrateur, si l'attitude de la Commission Municipale et du Ministère a pu être un instant équivoque, elle ne l'est plus depuis longtemps :—

Dans la même séance où il faisait son importante déclaration, la Commission, comme pour lui donner un démenti, prit la décision suivante: " la Commission, considérant que " le règlement annoncé par l'Etat n'a pas été " jusqu'ici promulgué et qu'il pourrait encore " tarder ; qu'il y a urgence à adopter pour la " ville d'Alexandrie des mesures tendant à " prévenir et à réprimer les abus actuels, ren " voie la question au Comité du Contentieux " pour lui proposer un règlement provisoire, " au cas où, après un mois, le Gouvernement " n'aurait pas encore exécuté sa règlementation " générale ".
Voyons maintenant ce qu'en pense le Ministère. Nous reproduisons textuellement :

" Lecture est donnée d'une lettre du 22 " avril 1906 de S.E. le Ministre de l'Intérieur " informant que la question de la réglemen-" tation des poids et mesures est toujours à " l'étude et que malgré le désir du Gouverne-" ment de résoudre cette question avec le " moins de retard possible, il est à prévoir " que la promulgation des dispositions législa-" tives nécessaires dans ce but prendront un " certain temps. Si donc la Commission désire, " en attendant la promulgation générale, " prendre certaines mesures pour remédier " aux inconvénients dont elle se plaint, elle " pourra soumettre ces mesures au ministère, " mais elles ne sauraient, en tout cas, avoir " qu'au caractère provisoire. "

Il n'y a donc plus aucune opposition da Gouvernement à ce que la Municipalité fasse un réglement provisoire. Il y a même une invitations et de la part des Conseillers un ordre formel. Qu'attend donc M. l'Administrateur pour procéder à l'exécution de cette invitation et de cet ordre ? Il faut quelques jours seulement pour élaborer une réglementation provisoire que notre ville attend depuis des années et il y a six mois que le gouvernement a vainement donné son approbation.

L'Administration a-t-elle pour mission d'exécuter les ordres qui lui sont donnés par le Ministère et la Commission ? Si oui, c'est donc elle qui est seule responsable du retard apporté à la réglementation des poids et mesures.

div.head: LE DROIT INTERNATIONAL ET LES TITRES AU PORTEUR.
div.p: Gand, 23. — Dans la séance d'hier, l'Institut de droit international a recommandé à l'attention des Etats les observations suivantes pour la solution des conflits en matière de disparition involontaire (perte, vol, etc.), des titres au porteur.
1° C'est la loi da pays débiteur, et non la loi du pays où la disparition a eu lieu, qui doit être appliquée pour indemniser le porteur et pour créer le duplicata.

2° Les titres au porteur à n'importe quel pays appartienne le débiteur, ne peuvent être revendiqués par le dépossédé, du moment où ils ont été l'objet d'une transaction dans un pays où la revendication n'est pas admise, même dans le cas où au moment de la disparition le dépossédé se trouverait dans on pays où la revendication est admise.

Par contre, ils peuvent être revendiqués même dans le cas où le dépossédé aa moment de la disparition se trouverait dans un pays où la revendication n'est pas admise, si ces titres ont été l'objet d'une transaction dans un pays où la revendication est admise.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: La nouvelle élévation du taux d'escompte à 4 1/2 % a produit une mauvaise impression sur notre marché. On avait, en effet, débuté avec entrain et en hausse lorsque la nouvelle de cette élévation a causé une légère réaction. Somme toute, cependant, la cote n'a pas subi de recul appréciable et elle est même en hausse partielle.
Ce sont les banques qui ont le plus souffert : la National Bank revient à 26 3/4, l'Agricole à 9 11/16, et la Cassa di Sconto à 226 3/4, après avoir atteint an moment 231.
Par contre, la Nile Land s'avance à 15 13/16-7/8 en gain de 3/4, le Comptoir à 6 23/32 l'action et 45 la part de fondateur.
La Privilégiés Tramways d'Alexandrie remonte à 190, tandis que la Dividende continue à fléchir à 330.
Très ferme la Daïra à 16 15/16, l'Ordinary Khédivial Mail à 34/7 1/2, la Land Bank à 8 15/: 6 et l'Union Foncière à 6 livres acheteurs.
En revanche, la Deferred Delta fléchit à 12 3/4, les Nungovich à 17 7/16, les Delta Land à 3 15/32 et les Sucreries à 25 1/2.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres a encore baissé de 1/8 à 4 1/4 pour cent ; mais il est remonté à 4 3/8 le lendemain, par suite, assurément, de la publication de l'état de la Banque d'Angleterre établissant que la proportion de la réserve aux engagements est tombée de 47 1/2 à 42 7/8 pour cent.

Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a haussé de 1/8 vendredi à 86 5/8, pour revenir samedi à 86 1/2. L'Unifiée est restée invariée à 104 1/4. La National Bank a gagné, en ces deux jours, 1/4 de livre à 26 7/8. L'Agricole est demeurée inchangée à 9 3/4, de même que la Daïra à 16 3/4 et la Delta Light à 11 5/8.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a gagné 1 franc vendredi à 783 pour réactionner de 2 francs le lendemain à 781. La Banque d'Athènes a rétrogradé de 1 franc à 145.

Ici, le mois d'Octobre, qui inaugure la période habituelle de rentrée et de reprise des affaires, a été salué, ce matin, par une fermeté générale sur tonte la cote, par une certaine animation et par une reprise de bon aloi sur plusieurs valeurs, notamment sur la National Bank, qui a eu les honneurs de la séance, alors que, vendredi passé, elle éprouvait seule les effets de la réaction.

Elle a débuté à 26 5/8 pour atteindre les abords de 27 et clôturer à 26 15/16. L'Agricole a été négligée à 9 11/16. La Cassa di Sconto a avancé à 226-227 l'action ancienne et 219 la nouvelle. Le Comptoir Financier s'est inscrit à 6 11/16 l'action ancienne et 6 7/16 la nouvelle. La Banque d'Abyssinie a gagné 1/8 à 5 5/8 11/16.

Le Crédit Foncier s'est maintenu à 779-780. L'action Immobilière a progressé à 387 ; la part de fondateur a été échangée entre 740 et 745. En bonne demande, la Nile Land a gagné 1/2 livre à 15 3/16 1/4. L'Enterprise and Development a fait 12 1/2. Les Improvements ont passé de 5 7/16 à 5 9/16.
L'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a bénéficié de 1/16 à 4 1/4-5/16 ; la part de fondateur a été recherchée à 70-71. La part de fondateur Allotment est remontée à 128.
Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire se sont alourdies à 264.

Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich ont gagné 5/32 à 17 7/16 1/2. Les Egyptian se sont raffermis à 6 1/4 5/16. Les National ont réactionné à 3 15/16 ; par contre, la part de fondateur a avancé à 58.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont fait 3 1/2 9/16. Les Hookir ont été traités au pair. Les New Egyptian ont avancé à 30 sh. 3. L'action Estates a atteint 1 7/8 pour finir plus faible à 1 13/16 7/8 ; la part de fondateur a progressé à 11 7/8. La Khedivial Mail a été bien tenue à 35 sh. Les Oasis ont été demandés à 1 1/8-3 16.
Nous détachons d'une lettre de Paris, en date du 24 Septembre, le passage suivant. :

" L'amélioration qui a'est produite sur notre marché financier doit être attribuée à la tenue relativement ferme des fonds russes. Il y a, certes, d'autres causes de préoccupation, par exemple, le resserrement monétaire à Londres ; mais cette crise métallique semble avoir atteint son maximum, et on s'attend généralement à un déclin qui ne tardera pas à faire sentir ses conséquences heureuses. En tout cas, ce n'est pas cette circonstance, usuelle d'ailleurs à cette époque de l'année, qui inquiète notre spéculation et l'oblige à la réserve. Du relèvement seul des fonds russes, je le répète, par suite de l'apaisement, dépend la reprise des affaires avec la hausse qui en sera le résultat forcé. "
Les recettes de la Delta Light Railways Co. pour la semaine au 22 Septembre dernier se sont chiffrées par L.E. 4,359 contre 3,946 en 1905, soit en augmentation de L E. 413.
Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Avril 1906 ont atteint la somme de L.E. 97,912 contre 89,909 en 1905 soit en plus-value de L.E. 8,003 pour l'exercice courant.

div.head: THE LAND BANK OF EGYPT
div.p: BANQUE FONCIERE D'EGYPTE
Constituée le 10 Janvier 1905 par Décret de S.A. Le Khedive.
SOCIETE ANONYME EGYPTIENNE
au Capital de £1,000,000 entièrement verse.-Reserves £247,500.
Emission de 90,000 Obligations Hypothécaires 4% de Fcs. 500 au Porteur
INTERET ANNUEL : 20 Francs (net d'impôts présents et futurs).
Payables par coupons semestriels les 1er Janvier et 1er Juillet de chaque année.
La LAND BANK OF EGYPT prend à sa charge les impôts français présents et futurs et les impôts qui pourraient être établis en Egypte.
Les titres seront remboursables à 500 francs par voie de tirages annuels au plus tard en 75 ans.
Les tirages auront lieu le 1er Juin de chaque année et le remboursement des titres amortis s'effectuera le 1er Juillet suivant.
Le premier tirage aura lieu le 1er Juin 1907.
L'intérêt attaché aux titres cessera à partir du jour fixé pour le remboursement.
Les coupons échus et les titres sortis au tirage seront payables à Paris en monnaie française, ainsi qu'en Egypte, à Londres, Bruxelles, Bâle, Genève et Amsterdam, au cours du change à vue sur Paris.
Les coupons échus et le capital des titres amortis seront périmés dans un délai de 30 ans.
Prix D'Emission : Fcs. 475 (Jouissance du 1er Juillet 1906)

row.cell: A la répartition du 16 au 20 Octobre. . . ... „ 375;

„ 175 — du 16 au 20 Novembre,
en supportant sur ce dernier versement un intérêt de 4 % à compter du 16 Octobre.

Les versements effectués postérieurement aux dates précitées seront passibles d'un intérêt 5 % l'an, qui courra du premier jour fixé pour le paiement de chaque terme et les Obligations pourront être vendues, sans mise en demeure, un mois après l'échéance du terme dû pour le Compte et aux risques et périls des intéressés.
The Land Bank of Egypt.
La souscription sera ouverte le 8 Octobre 1906 et close le même jour.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien AVIS
div.p: L'Administration a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Pablic qu'elle recevra jusqu'au 15 Novembre prochain à midi des offres pour fournitures de bureau pour l'année 1907 conformément aux échantillons déposés aux Magasins Généraux à Boulac (Caire) et à Gabbary ( Alexandrie) ou l'on peut obtenir copie da cahier des charges contre paiement de 150 m/ms. (cent cinquante millièmes). Les soumissionnaires doivent verser à la Caisse Centrale de l'Administration une garantie provisoire égale à 5% du montant de leurs offres et dont reçu devra être attaché à celles-ci.
Les offres devront être accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de 30 millièmes. Elles seront adressées par la poste sous pli recommandé à :
Monsieur le Directeur des Magasins,
Chemins de fer de l'Etat, Boulac (Caire),
et sous double enveloppe l'intérieure portant la suscription suivante:
"Offre pour fournitures de bureau."
L'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter l'offre la plus basse ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées; elle se réserve le droit de diviser la commande.
Le Caire, le 29 Septembre 1906. 28595-2-2

div.head: THE SULTAN'S HEALTH. PROFESSOR BERGMANN'S VIEW.
div.p: A Laffan despatch from Stamboul, under date of the 21st ult., says :

I have learned to-day from an absolutely reliable source that the Sultan's malady is stone in the bladder, the same ailment to which Napoleon III. succumbed after an opera tion performed on him in Chislehurst. The operation to which the Sultan submitted on August 10 was far less dangerous, the disease not having made such ravages as it had with Napoleon, whose constitution was pretty nearly undermined at the time of the operation. Abdul Hamid has passed the forty days after Noureddin Pasha's successful operation in comparatively good health. His actual condition, as Professor von Bergmann told me to-day, is quite satisfactory. He describes the Sultan as being pale and in need of rest, but showing good spirits, and exhibiting distinct symptoms of recovery. The greatest source of danger, the German specialist added, was not so much the possibility of a relapse, but the fact that the Sultan wants to attend to every detail of State business personally, thereby overtaxing bis strength. The Sultan sometimes refers jocularly to the newspaper reports, which describe him as being near death ; at other times, however, he is greatly irritated at these reports, on account of their political bearing.

Professor von Bergmann strongly recommended to him that he should allow daily or semiweekly reports signed by him (Bergmann) to be given out to the Press. Thereby the wild rumours which have been springing up ever since the Sultan's sickness became known would be brought to an end—rumours which were immensely multiplied, and have found an ever-increasing circle of believers, owing to the incredible and unparalleled stupidity of the Palace people, who insisted on making the world believe that his Majesty was suffering simply from a slight cold, when every beggar in the remotest corner of the Empire knew that the Sultan was, if not deadly, quite seriously sick. Professor von Bergmann represented to the Sultan that reports issued and signed by him would find credence everywhere, and put an end to the activity of the canard monger. The Sultan yielded. Professor von Bergmann and his assistant, Professor Bier, drew up, in communion with the Sultan's physicians in ordinary, a long report explaining the origin, progress, and actual state of the Monarch's sickness, and then presented it to the Sultan, with a strong recommendation that it should be published in the Turkish Press, The Sultan consented, but up to this date nothing has appeared in the papers, nor will anything appear later on. The notorious Palace clique had succeeded in convincing the Sultan that to bear out Professor von Bergmann's advice would have a very detrimental effect upon the populace. And the Sultan, as usual, yielded to this clique.

div.head: THE WELLCOME LABORATORIES.
div.p: The second report of the Wellcome Research Laboratories at Khartoum has just been issued in a handsome quarto volume of 255 pages, enriched by several excellent plates, coloured and uncoloured, in addition to numerous photographs and maps.

These laboratories were established three years ago at the Gordon Memorial College, Khartoum, by Mr. Henry S. Wellcome as a free gift to the Sudan Government, and are intended, among other objects, to promote the study of tropical disorders, especially the infective diseases of both man and beast ; to study the toxic agents employed by the natives ; to carry out such chemical and bacteriological tests in connection with water, food stuffs, health, and sanitary matters as may be found desirable, and to undertake the testing and assaying of agricultural, mineral, and other substances of practical interest in the industrial development of the Sudan, The director, Dr. Andrew Balfour, has been so successful in his pioneer work that his staff has been strengthened by the addition of a chemist (Dr. William Beam) and a travelling pathologist and naturalist (Dr. Sheffield Neave). A valuable adjunct in the shape of a floating laboratory will likewise be placed at his disposal before long. He has enlisted, moreover, the sympathies of several officers, both medical and veterinary, employed by the Sudan Government, and is getting much assistance from them as collectors and inquirers.

The "mosquito brigade" has been doing good work, not only in Khartoum, but in the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan generally, and the report gives statistics on the subject. There are valuable papers on other biting insects besides the mosquito, including the deadly tsetse fly. There is one on vegetal pests by Mr. F. V. Theobald, and one by Dr. Balfour on trypanosomiasis in cattle and mules.

An institution of this comprehensive character must needs prove of incalculable benefit to the country with which it is more immediately concerned, while it cannot fail to act as a useful auxiliary to home schools of tropical medicine.

div.head: RELIGIONS IN MALTA. LORD ELGIN'S REBUKE TO THE ARCHBISHOP.
div.p: A despatch from the Secretary of State for the Colonies, relative to the holding of Protestant mission services in the Theatre Royal, Malta, was published last week. It is the sequel of the action taken by the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Malta in protesting against the holding of a Protestant mission in Malta, and insisting to the Governor that it should be forthwith stepped. Writing on August 15th to the Governor of the island, Lord Elgin says :—

' The circumstances connected with the mission services held in the Theatre Royal at Malta, daring last May, by the Rev. J. McNeill, have directed the attention of his Majesty's Government to the general question of the treatment of different religious denominations in that island.

"The only basis which his Majesty's Government can admit for the settlement of the question is that all denominations should be treated with perfect equality. They are not aware of any pledges given by their predecessors, or of any circumstances peculiar to Malta, which preclude them from proceeding on that basis, or would justify them in denying to one religious body privileges granted to another.

"There is fortunately but one respect in which the existing conditions need alteration in order to carry out the principle of perfect equality and mutual toleration between different religions. The only practical restriction upon the religious ceremonies of other dominations than the Roman Catholic Church is that they are not permitted to take place in public. Whatever may have been the grounds on which it was originally imposed, such a restriction is plainly inconsistent with the principle which his Majesty's Government desires to see followed, and you will acordingly raise no objection in future to the holding in public of the religions ceremonies of any denomination, provided, of course, that they are bona fide religions ceremonies, and not in the nature of demonstrations intended to give offence.

"In order to make clear beyond doubt the view which his Majesty's Government take of the question, I propose to advise his Majesty to issue Royal Instructions amending the present instructions by the insertion of the following clause: 'It being Our intention that all persons inhabiting Oar said island should have fall liberty of conscience and the free exercise of their respectives modes of religious worship, We do hereby require Our said Governor and Commander-in-Chief to permit all persons within Our said Island to have such liberty, and to exercise their respective modes of religions worship, provided they be contented with a quiet and peaceable enjoyment of the same, not giving offence or scandal to the Government.'

"His Majesty's Government trust that the people of Malta, recognizing the principle of toleration which inspires the decision conveyed in this despatch, will accord to the public ceremonies of other Churches and denominations the same respect as to those of the Roman Catholic Church. If, however, disturbances should be caused by evil-disposed persons they must, of course, be repressed, if necessary by the whole power of the Government, and the persons causing them dealt with in accordance with law ; but his Majesty's Government earnestly hope that you will be confronted with no such necessity in carrying out a policy based on the fundamental principles of British liberty."

div.head: NILE VALLEY COMPANY.
div.p: Under date September 17 the managing director of the Nile Valley (New) Company, Limited, writes to the "African World" :—

I see in the "Egyptian Notes" of your paper of the 15th inst. yon draw attention to the fact that Mr. Noel Griffin has been appointed manager of the Nile Valley (New) Company, Limited. Yon farther congratulate the shareholders upon having secured his services, stating that 'the development of the property should soon show marked progress under his able management."

I quite agree that the board are to be congratulated upon having secured the services of Mr. Griffin upon so short a notice, but I would like to draw attention to the fact that the board were quite satisfied with their late manager, Mr. Norman Whyte.

Mr. Norman Whyte had been in the company's service for several years—almost since its inception—and showed such marked ability that when, a few months back, the post of manager became vacant the board had no hesitation in appointing him to fill it, as they recognised his great capabilities.
He, unfortunately, died at his post on the 8th inst., and in him my directors feel that the company has lost a tried and trusted employé.

div.head: LANCASHIRE COTTON MILLS.
div.p: In his private cotton trade circular, issued last week, Mr. William Tattersall, of Manchester, gives a list of new cotton spinning mills : 28 factories, containing 2,400,000 spindles, have got to work during the last 12 months or so, 13, with 1,100,000 spindles, have partly started, and 37 mills are being erected, the spindles of which are 3,100,000. The total is 78 mills and 6,600.000 spindles. Three new mills are projected, thought the cost is 15 per cent, more than a year ago, owing partly to the rise in steel. Operatives are getting scarce. Labour in one staple trade was never in such demand.

div.head: INDIAN AGITATION. A STRONG WARNING.
div.p: Commenting on the part played by the Indian vernacular Press in the spread of disloyal agitation among the Bengalis, the Allahabad ' Pioneer" observes that, contemptible as the editors of these papers frequently are, the number of natives able to read their own vernacular is increasing daily, and the native anti-British newspaper is their only source of information. It is idle for the Government to rely on the justice meted out by its officers and their assiduity in promoting local interests as a refutation of the cunningly devised lies of the native Press. "The justice and the assiduity are no new thing ; but the agitation grows." Two courses appear open. Rigorous suppression of the seditious Presses or stately disregard of them. The first, says the "Pioneer," "would alienate the sympathies of that vast percentage of the British electorate which is so supremely ignorant of Indian affairs, and would provide the extremists with a platform cry nearly as efficacious as that of 'Chinese Labour.' Therefore, it seems, the evil must grow and prosper until it has borne its fruit."

The agitators have at present a free hand for mischief, but it is the people who have to be considered. "The spectacle is a pitiful one, when the deep potentialities for evil—probably but dimly recognised by the ringleaders themselves—are considered. They are fast creating a Frankenstein monster, which, when its time is completed, will inevitably avenge the horrors to which it will be exposed on the reckless authors of its being. Such a monster will he easier for us to deal with than nebulous vapourings in many vernaculars. The matter will then have passed from the stage of verbiage to that of action ; from the quibbles of the Law Courts to the tribunal from which there is no appeal ; and before which many of the learned members of the native legal profession will be in no haste to appear. It is not meet that the sower should he absent at harvest time."

The Calcutta ' Englishman" publishes a remarkable circular emanating from a native secret society. Its tenor may be gathered from the following extracts : ' Golden Bengal —Fifty thousand people are required to die ; you all be ready. What is the good of crying any more ? The only thing is to give blood from the heart. Wherever you are assembled together, you promise, that you will break the nests of the Feringhi Babui-birds, tearing them into pieces and throwing them into the water of the Ganges. Until we do this we shall not see our interests looked after.

"Come, brother wherever you are—Brahmin, Kayasta Sudra, Chundal, Mussulman, Christian, who is thinking it glory to style himself 'Son of Bengal.' Come, brothers ; assemble together ; let ns forget all mean self interest.

"Why are we blind not to see before us how unfortunate we are? Feringhis are making our mother naked. Why does not blood flow from our eyes ? Who is insulting our golden mother? Bengalis are not cowards or un-grateful. Brothers, Hindus and Mussulmans, gird your loins for the honour of your mother. Since all must one day die, why fear ? Make strong your hearts. You will see that a crore of people will come and stand by you ; you will see that by the exertion of a crore of people the guns, ballets, and bayonets of the Feringhi people will disappear.

"Take these with you, assemble and give loud cries, beat the sahibs of the city, drive them away. We will govern our own country. Do not care for the police, do not fear guns or bayonets. Delay not, delay not; delay will ruin all. Rise all ! Now is the very moment !"

The reply of the "Pioneer" to this outburst as follows : "Let no man, native or European, labour under any delusion. The British hold India and mean to continue their supremacy. If the Bengalis acted upon the advice that is given to them and did begin to cast 'Feringhi people' into the Ganges, we would descend upon them with fire and sword, and we would shoot and hang as remorselessly as in 1857—perhaps even more so."

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Major H. M. Finch, Royal Berkshire Regiment, has been posted to the 1st Battalion on promotion from the 2nd Battalion at Khartoum, and Captain F. W. Foley, on absorption, joins the 2nd Battalion.

The vacancy for a captain in the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers has been filled by the promotion of Lieutenant A. J. M. Gordon of the 1st Battalion, Belfast. Captain Gordon, got his commission in October, 1899, and served with the 1st Battalion in the fight for the relief of Ladysmith, including Colenso, and the operations in the Transvaal, the actions of Belfast, and Lydenburgh (Queen's medal with four clasps).

With reference to the foot note to paragraph 76 of the King's Regulation, 1904, the Royal Standard, being the personal flag of the Sovereign, will not be displayed in the future on Fortresses, or Official Buildings, as has hitherto been customary, on his Majesty's Birthday and other occasions, but will be only hoisted when the Sovereign is actually present, or when any member of the Royal Family is present, representing the Sovereign. The Royal Standard is to be used for the Queen in the same manner as for his Majesty. As the occasion for all Royal Salutes are officially notified, the use of the Royal Standard is unnecessary when royal salutes are fired in the absence of the Sovereign.
It has been ordered that commanding officers most be present with their units when mobilisation equipment is being inspected.
It has been intimated that the period of furlough at home of soldiers on the Indian or Colonial establishment is to reckon as Indian or Colonial service.

It is stated that important changes in naval organisation will be shortly made. The Atlantic Fleet will be divided into three divisions, an English. Irish, and Scottish one. The latter will be based on Rossyth, and will be practically a North Sea squadron, the Irish one will have its base at Berehaven, and the English squadron will base on Dover. Each squadron will he commanded by a vice-admiral, with a rear-admiral second in command, and Lord Charles Beresford will be in supreme command. It is said that the present formation of the Atlantic Fleet with its base on Gibraltar would not permit of it speedily reinforcing the Channel Fleet in time of war in home waters. In the latter case, that duty would devolve on the Irish division. The North Sea Division will be strongest, and we need hardly say that it will be a practical answer to German naval aggression. The whole trend of British naval opinion is, that the next naval war, so far as England is concerned, will be in home waters, and to that end she is concentrating her forces, and getting them into hand for any contingency that the complicated character of Continental politics may occasion. It will no doubt be noticed that the entente cordiale is responsible for the practical abolition of the ceaseless naval patrols along the French, Portuguese, and Spanish coasts.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
